title: Super slow addition of an existing subdaset within a top of "rich" hierarchy

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Improve performance of an existing feature

body:
#### What is the problem?
may be it is echo of #1467 , may be already fixed in master (I was using 0.9.x at this point).

```shell
(dev)2 11161.....................................:Fri 08 Dec 2017 12:05:17 AM EST:.
(git)smaug:/mnt/btrfs/datasets/datalad/crawl[master]git
$> git status --ignore-submodules=dirty
On branch master
Your branch is ahead of 'datalad-public/master' by 1 commit.
  (use "git push" to publish your local commits)

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

        modified:   abide2 (new commits)
        modified:   indi (new commits)

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

        abide-TODOs
        abide/
        hbn-TODOs
        hbn/
        princeton-dataspace/

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
(dev)2 11162.....................................:Fri 08 Dec 2017 12:05:19 AM EST:.
(git)smaug:/mnt/btrfs/datasets/datalad/crawl[master]git
$> datalad add -d . -m "adding abide dataset" abide

add(ok): abide (dataset) [added new subdataset]
add(notneeded): abide (dataset) [nothing to add from /mnt/btrfs/datasets/datalad/crawl/abide]
add(notneeded): .gitmodules (file) [already included in the dataset]
save(ok): /mnt/btrfs/datasets/datalad/crawl (dataset)
action summary:
  add (notneeded: 2, ok: 1)
  save (ok: 1)
datalad add -d . -m "adding abide dataset" abide  4.65s user 25.38s system 8% cpu 6:00.18 total
(dev)2 11163.....................................:Fri 08 Dec 2017 12:11:39 AM EST:.
```
so it took 6 minutes (!) for a simple *add a new submodule*.  I bet it was due to the fact that again full recursive listing of submodules was invoked to decide on the destiny of the path. 

To reproduce -- just go to one of those snapshots of the entire collection and try to add new pre-populated datasets.

#### What version of DataLad are you using (run `datalad --version`)? On what operating system (consider running `datalad plugin wtf`)?
0.9.1-137-g104c7864  in a bugfix branch on top of 0.9.x
